August 11, 1991: Fiction
THE KITCHEN GOD'S WIFE, by Amy Tan. (Putnam, $22.95.) A Chinese-
American matriarch tells the harrowing story of her life.
THE FIRM, by John Grisham. (Doubleday, $19.95.) A young lawyer learns that his
firm is engaged in secret, possibly illegal activities.
HEIR TO THE EMPIRE, by Timothy Zahn. (Spectra/Bantam, $15.) The survival of
the "Star Wars" galaxy is menaced by new forces.
LOVES MUSIC, LOVES TO DANCE, by Mary Higgins Clark. (Simon & Schuster,
$21.95.) Two women get caught in the snare of a serial killer.
BEAST, by Peter Benchley. (Random House, $21.) The disappearance of a
couple off Bermuda raises a question: is a creature from the deep responsible?
OUTER BANKS, by Anne Rivers Siddons. (HarperCollins, $19.95.) An interior
decorator comes to terms with herself at a college reunion.
PARADISE, by Judith McNaught. (Pocket, $19.95.) The heirs of two family
dynasties find true love when one of their businesses is threatened.
PASTIME, by Robert B. Parker. (Putnam, $19.95.) The private eye Spenser learns
much about his own past while helping a young man track down his mother, who
has disappeared.
MAXIMUM BOB, by Elmore Leonard. (Delacorte, $20.) A woman probation officer
pursues the people trying to kill a redneck Florida judge.
OH, THE PLACES YOU'LL GO! by Dr. Seuss. (Random House, $12.95.) Verse
and pictures.
TEXAS! SAGE, by Sandra Brown. (Doubleday, $18.) A young woman who has
always been able to wrap men around her finger meets her match on a visit to her
hometown.
AS THE CROW FLIES, by Jeffrey Archer. (HarperCollins, $22.95.) A man strives
to create the biggest store in the world.
DARKNESS, by John Saul. (Bantam, $17.50.) A family moves back to a Florida
town, where something evil awaits.
SKY MASTERS, by Dale Brown. (Fine/Putnam, $21.95.) The United States Air
Force comes to the aid of the Philippines in a war with China in 1994.
THE RUSTLERS OF WEST FORK, by Louis L'Amour. (Bantam, $18.) A frontier
novel featuring Hopalong Cassidy, first published in 1951.
August 11, 1991
Non-Fiction
IRON JOHN, by Robert Bly. (Addison-Wesley, $19.95.) The passage of the male
from boyhood into manhood, as practiced in various cultures.
CHUTZPAH, by Alan M. Dershowitz. (Little, Brown, $22.95.) A prominent law
professor's reflections on the lot of Jews in America.
PARLIAMENT OF WHORES, by P. J. O'Rourke. (Entrekin/Atlantic Monthly,
$19.95.) A humorist's attempt to explain the Federal Government.
TOUJOURS PROVENCE, by Peter Mayle. (Knopf, $20.) The charms of rustic
Provence, as savored by a London advertising man who moved there.
WHEN YOU LOOK LIKE YOUR PASSPORT PHOTO, IT'S TIME TO GO HOME,
by Erma Bombeck. (HarperCollins, $19.95.) The tribulations of travel suffered in all
parts of the world.
FIRE IN THE BELLY, by Sam Keen. (Bantam, $19.95.) The changing role of
today's male.
A QUESTION OF CHARACTER, by Thomas C. Reeves. (Free Press, $24.95.) A
biography of John F. Kennedy.
BOSS OF BOSSES, by Joseph F. O'Brien and Andris Kurins. (Simon & Schuster,
$22.95.) The downfall of the mobster Paul Castellano.
WOODY ALLEN, by Eric Lax. (Knopf, $24.) The life of the film director, writer and
actor.
THE COMMANDERS, by Bob Woodward. (Simon & Schuster, $24.95.) How
President Bush and his commanders have made military decisions.
THE DAY AMERICA TOLD THE TRUTH, by James Patterson and Peter Kim.
(Prentice Hall, $19.95.) Americans' beliefs about sex, drugs and many other
matters, as revealed through a poll.
COUNSEL TO THE PRESIDENT, by Clark Clifford with Richard Holbrooke.
(Random House, $25.) The memoirs of the Democratic adviser.
ILLIBERAL EDUCATION, by Dinesh D'Souza. (Free Press, $19.95.) A critical
account of the way matters of race and sex are treated on campus.
PETER LAWFORD, by James Spada. (Bantam, $22.50.) The life of the British-
born actor, Hollywood man about town and Kennedy in-law.
UNDER THE INFLUENCE, by Peter Hernon and Terry Ganey. (Simon &
Schuster, $24.95.) An unauthorized account of Anheuser-Busch.
